title: Slack activation for small teams
prompt: Slack's free-to-paid conversion rate is 3.5%. Analysis shows the gap isn't feature awareness   it's that small teams (5-15 people) never hit the "aha moment" of cross-channel workflows. They use Slack like a chat app. You're the PM. How do you activate small teams without being annoying?
problemDefinition: Small teams don't experience the collaboration workflow that drives paid conversion
Feature awareness isn't the issue; behavior change is
Onboarding changes risk annoying users and hurting retention

options.label: Discovery-first
options.text: Interview small teams to understand why they never reach the workflow aha.

options.label: Pick the wedge
options.text: Target one segment (e.g., engineering) and design a tailored onboarding flow.

options.label: Ship now
options.text: Launch guided onboarding nudges this week and measure activation lift.

options.label: Growth loop
options.text: Define activation (cross-channel workflow) and run experiments to lift it.

options.label: Admins
options.text: Enable admins to set up workflows and seed behavior.

options.label: End users
options.text: Guide everyday users to create cross-channel habits.

options.label: Segment wedge
options.text: Pick a team type (design, support) and build onboarding for them.

options.label: Everyone
options.text: Roll out nudges broadly and iterate based on data.

options.label: Trust vs growth
options.text: If nudges are annoying, we lose trust even if activation rises.

options.label: Strategic focus
options.text: Choosing the right segment without overfitting onboarding.

options.label: Speed
options.text: If we wait, conversion stagnates and revenue misses targets.

options.label: Activation
options.text: If the aha moment is unclear, experiments won t help.

theSplit.question: Should Slack push guided onboarding aggressively or keep it subtle to protect trust?

sides.reasoning: Activation requires behavior change; strong nudges drive it faster.
Trust and value must be validated before heavy nudges.
Choose a segment and design for them, not everyone.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: Validate the value of the workflow before nudging it
cagan.spicyQuote: If you shove teams into workflows they don't value, you're creating churn, not activation.
breakdown: Value risk: do small teams actually want structured workflows?
Usability risk: nudges can be annoying if value is unclear
Viability risk: aggressive onboarding can hurt brand trust
The best companies validate value before forcing behavior change
solution: Interview small teams about collaboration pain points
Prototype workflow nudges and test value perception
Define go/no-go criteria on trust and activation
Scale only when value risk clears
cagan.disagreement: Execution AI Monster and Lenny will push aggressive nudges without proving teams value the workflow. Doshi's wedge is smart, but still needs validation of which segment truly values it. Torres aligns on discovery but must define hard outcome thresholds.

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map opportunities that lead to the workflow aha
torres.spicyQuote: If we don't understand why teams avoid workflows, our nudges are just noise.
breakdown: Define desired outcome (activation + paid conversion)
Map opportunities: onboarding, templates, team rituals
Weekly interviews with small teams
Test opportunity branches before scaling
solution: Build an Opportunity Solution Tree
Run weekly interviews + prototype tests
Compare onboarding concepts
Ship only after evidence accumulates
torres.disagreement: Cagan's risk framing is aligned, but continuous evidence is required. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will ship nudges without understanding the opportunity space. Doshi's wedge is fine, but you still need evidence that this segment cares about workflows.

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.summary: Pick a segment wedge and design activation for them
doshi.spicyQuote: If you try to design activation for everyone, you end up activating no one.
breakdown: This is a strategy problem, not an onboarding tweak
Opportunity cost: broad nudges annoy everyone
Pre-mortem: churn, spammy UX, low activation
Wedge focus is the leverage move
solution: Pick a segment (e.g., engineering or support)
Design workflow templates for that segment
Run a pre-mortem and set success criteria
Expand only if wedge proves durable
doshi.disagreement: Torres will map for weeks while conversion stalls. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will push broad nudges and annoy users. Cagan is right about value risk, but he needs a sharper wedge strategy, not just validation.

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Define activation and run onboarding experiments fast
lenny.spicyQuote: Slack is a growth loop. If the activation moment isn't hit, nothing else matters.
breakdown: Define activation: cross-channel workflow in week 1
Map loop: invite -> channel -> workflow -> retention
Benchmark against high-performing work tools
Run experiments to lift activation
solution: Instrument onboarding funnel
Run experiments on nudges and templates
Scale highest-lift variant
Iterate weekly based on data
lenny.disagreement: Torres wants more discovery, but the loop is measurable now. Cagan's risk framing is good, but experiments answer it faster. Doshi's wedge is fine, but you still need the loop to work. Execution AI Monster is fast, but needs measurement discipline.

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship guided onboarding now and measure lift
exec.spicyQuote: You can debate activation theory or ship a guided flow this week and see if it works.
breakdown: Building is discovery   ship to learn
Guided onboarding is cheap to test
Speed beats perfect research
Iterate weekly based on data
solution: Launch guided onboarding to 10% of teams
Monitor activation daily
Adjust nudges weekly
Scale if lift holds
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will still be interviewing while conversion stays flat. Doshi's wedge is smart but too slow. Lenny is close, but don't wait for perfect benchmarks   ship and learn.
